sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &appname; is an image viewer application for your GNOME desktop.
The &appname; application is able to show a frame on your desktop in which are displayed images and photos gathered from user specified local and online sources.
This manual describes how to set up and use the &appname; application.

sect1.title: Starting &appname;
sect1.para: To start &appname; select the ApplicationsGraphics Photo Frame entry from the main menu.
Alternatively start &appname; from the shell with the gphotoframe command.
As the &appname; application is started and the photo frame displayed, you could start to add sources. Do this in the following way:

listitem.para: Right-click on the photo frame and select Preferences from the &appname; main menu.
Select the Photos tab and press the New button.
In the dialog that will open, select one of the many sources. Adjust as desired the options and apply the changes with the Ok button.
Go back to the photo frame by closing the Preferences dialog with the Close button.

note.para: Some sources may require an active internet connection in order to display images.

sect1.title: Photo Frame
sect1.para: The photo frame is the main window of &appname;.

When an image or photo is diplayed, hovering on it with the mouse pointer will make some icons and a tooltip appears as showed in . The tooltip shows some basic informations about the content as the author name, the image title and the date taken.

note.title: Clutter library support
note.para: Without the Clutter library support, these icons will not be displayed. You will see only the tooltip.

sect1.para: The number and type of icons displayed on the frame corners depends on the content’s source. They can be:

If you are logged in with your userID to an internet service like Flickr, you could add an image to your’s profile favorites with a click on this icon. The icon will then light up indicating that the image has been added to your favorites.
Click again on that icon and the image will be removed from your favorites.

If the contents comes from photo manager applications (such as F-Spot or Shotwell database), there will be a row of five icons so that you can assign a personal vote to the content displayed with a click on them.

This icon is located on the bottom right of the frame and depict a camera. If you hover the mouse on it, a tooltip will be displayed containing all the image’ metadata (if available) such as camera model and maker, shutter speed, aperture, etc...

With a click on the icon, the source will open in your system’s default web browser (if the content comes from an online service), and in your system’s default image viewer (if the content is local).

sect1.para: The &appname; menu could be opened with a right click inside the photo frame.
In the menu there are the following entries:

Shows a list of names of recently displayed images and allow the user to open a webpage that displays the images history.

Toggle the fullscreen visualization of &appname;.
When this option is activated, the photo frame can not be dragged wih the mouse and it’s shape is not displayed in the pager.

note.para: When &appname; is in fix mode, all shortcut keys are invalid.

Shows the application’s developers and contributors informations as well as the version number.

sect1.title: Setting the Preferences
sect1.para: The Preferences dialog is accessible with a right click inside the photo frame and selecting Preferences from the menu.
In the Preferences dialog there are three tabs.

sect2.title: General tab
sect2.para: In the General tab you can set some general options for &appname;.
The General tab is composed of three subsections:

listitem.para: Sets the visualization time, in seconds, of an image for the window mode and for the full screen mode.
The maximum display size of the displayed image could be set in the width and height fields.

note.title: Image resizing
note.para: The original image is always resized (not cropped). In particular, the image is scaled down so that it’s smallest dimension (width or height) fits the value set in the General tab.

listitem.para: Enable the Visible on All Workspaces option to make &appname; visible on all workspaces.
Check the Auto Start option to load automatically &appname; on next system’s startup.

sect2.title: Plugins tab
sect2.para: This tab shows the list of plugins currently installed on your system.

Plugins can be enabled or disabled with a click on the check box on the left of the plugin’s name. With a click on the About button in the bottom right when a plugin row is highlighted, will display a dialog containing some information regarding the selected plugin.
&appname; ships with the following pre-installed plugins:

listitem.para: F-Spot — shows in &appname; the images in your F-Spot database.

Flickr — display the contents from the popular photo sharing service. This plugin is highly customizable as you can look for photos by specifying a tag, a group, a user or by showing the most interesting or the latest content.
Folder — with this plugin you could add as a source for content a folder that contains image files on your computer.
Picasa Web — display the contents from the google photo hosting service.
RSS and Atom feed — shows images from a RSS or Atom feed.
Ruins clock — gather images of old and abandoned clocks from Haikyo Clock website.
Shotwell — shows in &appname; the images in your Shotwell database.
Tumblr — shows images from the share anything online service.

sect2.title: Photos tab
sect2.para: From the Photos tab you can manage (Add, Delete or Edit) the content’s sources.

sect3.title: Adding a source
sect3.para: To add a source of contents to &appname;, click the New button.

In the dialog that will appear, select a source from the pop-up list. Depending on the type of source selected (folder, F-Spot or Shotwell database, internet sharing services as Flickr, Tumblr or Picasa) different settings are available. Configure them to your liking and then press Ok. A new source will be added to the list and the new content will start to be displayed on the photo frame.
If you want to add more sources just repeat this process.

note.title: Weight
note.para: One of the most important setting if you have more than one source, is weight: the content from the source with the highest weight will be displayed more frequently.

sect3.title: Deleting a source
sect3.para: To remove a source just highlight the relative row in the list and press the Delete button.

sect3.title: Editing a source
sect3.para: To modify the settings for an existing source, highlight it’s name with a click in the list and press the Preferences button to open the settings dialog.

sect1.title: Showing the images history
sect1.para:
&appname; allows you to see the history of displayed images in a web browser. Select Open RecentShow History from the &appname; Application Menu. A web page will be opened in your default web browser with all the images displayed in the current session sorted in appearence order (from latest to oldest). For every image, you can see many information as the title, the source, the author’s name and the date taken.
Click on any image to open it directly in the source.

sect1.title: Removing a displayed image
sect1.para: Removing a displayed image is accomplished by clicking on the icons that appears in the bottom left of the &appname; window when hovering over a displayed photo.

listitem.para: To move to the trash a displayed image, click on the trash shaped icon in the lower left of the photo frame. A dialog will appear to confirm the operation.

note.para: This icon is showed only if the displayed image comes from a local source such as a local folder or a F-spot or Shotwell database.

listitem.para: To remove from catalog a displayed image coming from a F-spot database, click on the minus sign in the lower left of the photo frame. A dialog will appear to confirm the operation.
To ban a photo coming from an online source (Flickr, Tumbler etc...), press the minus icon that appears in the bottom left when hovering over the displayed photo.

sect1.title: Logging to an Online Service
sect1.para: In &appname; is possible to get logged in to an online service listed in the Plugins tab if you have an account.
When &appname; is connected with your data to an online service, you could add displayed contents to your favorites, vote images and display photos from your account.
To do so, follow these steps:

listitem.para: Go to the Plugins tab and highlight the row of the online service plugin you want to get logged in.
Press the Preferences button to open the login dialog.
Insert the information requested (user ID, e-mail address, password etc...).
Press Ok and follow the instructions provided by the dialog.

note.para: Depending on the service you are logging in, a web browser window might be opened so that you can give &appname; the required permissions through the online service’s webpages. When you terminate this task, go back to &appname; and follow the instructions in the dialog.

sect1.title: Using &appname; as Screensaver
sect1.para: &appname; can also be used as screensaver.
The screensaver should be configured automatically at installation time.

Open the application that manages the screensavers in your system and you should see an entry named Photo Frame. Select it and that’s all. The next time the screensaver will starts, the sources preferences will be read as configured from the main window of &appname; and consequently will display the contents.
